fields.headline: A click away from immortality
fields.bodyText: An astronaut. Photograph: Sergei Karpukhin/AP If you have a hankering for online immortality you may want to check out Library of Life, a new site for people to record their lives in text, pictures and video. You can register material after paying a fee of £16.25, and the creators hope the site will raise £50,000 a year for charities, including the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. The Times had an interesting read about the site earlier this week that said it was hoped Library of Life could provide historians with a record of humanity in these days when letter writing is in decline. The site is up and running now but will not be properly launched and promoted until after Christmas. Now I know this is not in the spirit of the venture, but I wonder if I could embellish my personal history? It's amazing to think how I started my career as Nasa's youngest astronaut before winning the Nobel prizes for literature and world peace. And then when you add in the juggling ...
